abstract: Mitt Romney won the Illinois primary but opponents vow to continue, buoyed by “super PACs”; why some stand-up comics decide to go it alone; and the erotic novel “Fifty Shades of Grey” has enticed publishers, and now film producers.
snippet: Mitt Romney won the Illinois primary but opponents vow to continue, buoyed by “super PACs”; why some stand-up comics decide to go it alone; and the erotic novel “Fifty Shades of Grey” has enticed publishers, and now film producers.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney won the Republican presidential primary in Illinois, beating his nearest opponent, Rick Santorum, by a sizable margin and adding substantially to his lead in delegates, Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny report. But if Mr. Romney thought the victory would give “closure” to the nomination fight, there was no such indication from his opponents who continue to be buoyed by “super PACs.”

headline.main: The Breakfast Meeting: Romney Must Slog On, and Studios Pursue ’50 Shades’
